title: Towards a computational account of natural sequential behavior
descriptions:
This grant proposal, titled "Towards a computational account of natural sequential behavior," aims to develop computational models that can identify and characterize perception, cognition, and action in everyday tasks. The goals of this project include understanding and modeling sequential actions involving perceptual uncertainty and action variability, as well as characterizing internal and external costs and benefits in the context of optimal sequential decision making under uncertainty.

The proposed methods involve conducting behavioral experiments and integrating various disciplines such as psychophysics, statistical decision theory, active vision, intuitive physics, optimal control under uncertainty, navigation, and inverse reinforcement learning. The tasks to be studied include classical psychophysical production tasks, visuomotor control, navigation, and even a real-world task like sandwich making.

The expected outcomes of this project include the recovery of subjects' perceptual uncertainties, beliefs about tasks, subjective costs and benefits including effort, and action variability. The research team has previous experience in experimental work on visuomotor behavior and theoretical work in modeling behavior on an individual-by-individual and trial-by-trial basis. This project will significantly advance our understanding of natural sequential behavior and its computational underpinnings.
